results.content:
Very good course that brought a lot of previous knowledge together for me as well as learning new things. Michael is a very good teacher, never rushed and always clear in his explanations. I have done a lot of online courses and this one is among the best- well structured taught by someone who not only knows the subject but who can communicate concepts clearly and in plain language. This is the first course I have done with this tutor and I would certainly do another...many thanks.

My only other feedback would be that It would be useful to have evolving copies of the code to download so you are not typing code while trying to listen to the lecture. That said, the course is about concepts more than coding and perhaps we should not be worrying about the detail of the code. However, there is quite bit of time spent looking at code and so it would help if this was made available as a downloadable text file.

results.content: Michael is an incredibly knowledgeable instructor who assumes no prior knowledge. The course content builds up from some very basic coding practices to complex interaction between client and database via a server. Although it was not expected that the exercises were completed I did indeed follow along and now have a fully-functional webapp that I can modify to suit my needs. For an introduction, this course covers an incredibly wide range of concepts covering not only the display and processing of spatial data but also some internet security measures and even a little history thrown in which makes it much easier to understand the possibilities and limitations of Web GIS. I am thoroughly looking forward to starting Michael's Leaflet course.

results.content:
I've been developing web applications with ESRI JS Api for about 3 years now. I was looking for free alternatives to 'Arcgis world' to be able to build these applications with cost close to zero and to be able to do some projects apart from my current job. Here I found the way.

I have to say that Michael Miller not only will introduce you to Leaflet, but he'll walk you through very fundamental concepts in web development and important technologies associated with it in a way that only an experienced developer could do it.

Thank you, sir Miller, for providing such a good content. I'm really satisfied with this course.

results.content: The course took six or seven hours reviewing basics of html, css, and javascript.  Then it took a great leap into some complicated code to use Leaflet.ajax.js to read an ajax file and add it it to a map and then add a pointtolayer option to create popups.  However when I tried this code using a test server, the code did did not work.  Has this code actually been tested?

response.content:
Charles, I just posted a response to your original question. I am not sure why I did not get a notification when you asked the question originally.  My goal is to answer every question within 24 hours and clearly I failed in this case and I apologize.  

First of all I have been very clear in this course that the intention is not to have students follow along in this introductory class.  I am working on a second class that is focused specifically on leaflet and in that class I DO expect students to follow along. I walk them through the basics of installing a web server and an editor and provide source code for both the beginning and end of each coding exercise.  

Second, I looked at your code and the problem was in the data file not the code.  I don't know where you got the data file as I did not provide any so I can't address the question of why it was wrong but there were semi-colons where colons should be and commas, missing etc.

I did add the data file to lecture 57. You can download it if you like.

Yes, the code was tested and it does work.
response.content_html:
Charles, I just posted a response to your original question. I am not sure why I did not get a notification when you asked the question originally. My goal is to answer every question within 24 hours and clearly I failed in this case and I apologize.

First of all I have been very clear in this course that the intention is not to have students follow along in this introductory class. I am working on a second class that is focused specifically on leaflet and in that class I DO expect students to follow along. I walk them through the basics of installing a web server and an editor and provide source code for both the beginning and end of each coding exercise.

Second, I looked at your code and the problem was in the data file not the code. I don't know where you got the data file as I did not provide any so I can't address the question of why it was wrong but there were semi-colons where colons should be and commas, missing etc.

I did add the data file to lecture 57. You can download it if you like.

Yes, the code was tested and it does work.

results.content:
I'm 
I enjoyed this course for the most part.  The instructor is thoughtful and describes what he is typing as he moves along in his code
However his narration of his coding covers usually the current event.   Meaning if you want to be constantly refreshed as to how the mechanics are tied together in terms of logical code review with repeated code breakdowns for better understanding, you may be dissapointed. If, however, you are good at puzzle solving or have time to dive deeper else where with respect to getting more instruction on gis ajax, and json language coding principles and conventions  with in depth usage examples, do so.
This course is sort of a gentle intro to the world of not a hands on step by step guide to these aforementioned language coding rules and conventions in terms of an scaffolding support ....
Example:Section 10 part 11-

"I'm going to create a new feature array, I'm going to create it with a new type property, and I'll set the new value of that property to the text 'feature'...now instead of putting this geometry object back into the row we're going to create a new element in the feature array with a geometry key and then I'm going to delete the old geometry element
out of the row array and going to create a new element in the feature array with a key of properties
and we're going to set that equal to the row array now that we've removed the geometry key
and then finally I'm going to push this new feature array into the features array,
and then down here I'm going to create a new array called featurecollection....."

He doesn't spend much time stepping back through his code much and explaining things like, "Do you remember when we did that?...well that led to this then this then this and that's why we'now need to do this here, otherwise this or that might not happen because... 

So yes it is a sort of introduction.
One might need to slow down and problem solve a lot on their own.  Having said that,

I am enjoying the course so far.  It is as advertised.

results.content:
The author justifies his qualification and motivation for this course with the fact that free applications can be developed. This saves thousands of dollars that would otherwise be paid to ESRI. It therefore seems as if the author is only motivated to reproduce ESRI technology as an alternative to commercial software. Throughout the course, ESRI technology is presented negatively. This is surprising as other commercial software is reported positively. It seems that the author just doesn't like ESRI. This is not neutral and very unfortunate. The author does not need that.
As a course participant and in a didactic environment, I expect neutrality.

Nevertheless, the course was good.

results.content: I'm so glad I found this course back in April. It was just what I needed in this ever evolving GIS industry. I might be exaggerating, but this course is worth more than its price tag. Mike is very experienced and knows what he's doing, he brings everything he has learned into the table. He has created a great series of courses which are all important if you want to be a GIS Developer/Programmer. I would also recommend his blog which has some very nice articles regarding GIS. I hope he keeps making great contents as he always does.

results.content: Perfect course for me.  It covered a lot of mandatory material that I knew must exist for both the web in general and GIS functionality specifically; but for which I knew little about.  All of this in a focused and comprehensive introduction to the key components required to establish a complete end to end workflow for getting GIS data onto the web without any extraneous distractions.  Describes data flows from one end of the pipe to the other, client to server, and back again.  Wonderfully comprehensive and yet concise; indeed a fine balance.  Yes, there is still stuff to learn but the bonus material was excellent as well.  I currently have another two of Mr. Miller's courses in the queue to look forward to and will likely buy the remaining two as well.  Fantastic value for the money--especially when discounted.
